If you're interested in learning more, I've linked the original report below.

Of course, remember this Grayscale report is just one opinion.

I'll break down more reports from leading players in future, so you can have a more holistic view of the market.

Use these opinions from industry leaders to inform your own strategy, but don't blindly follow them.

Here's the TLDR:

1.  ETFs have exposed crypto to a new class of investors
2. On-chain metrics have been super healthy
3. Retail isn't FULLY here yet
4. Be prepared for healthy drawdowns, and focus on the fundamentals when in doubt

Overall Grayscale Thesis:

Grayscale remains 'cautiously optimistic' about the future of this bull cycle.

They're looking forward to realising the impact of:

‚Ä¢ Sidelined institutional players entering the market
‚Ä¢ Investor behaviour of the 'new investor archetype'

4. Retail Market Sentiment

Retail interest hasn't yet fully returned this cycle.

‚Ä¢ Lower Crypto YT subscription rates vs. 2020-21 cycle
‚Ä¢ Lower Google Trends interest for "crypto" vs. 2021

This data suggests that a new investor demographic is driving this bull cycle. https://t.co/ls13Ro9oYY

3. ColinTalksCrypto Bitcoin Bull Run Index (CBBI)

CBBI gives a snapshot of broader market conditions, by integrating multiple ratios into one number.

Currently, CBBI is at 79/100, suggesting we're close to historical cycle peaks with some upward steam still left. https://t.co/jF5n95WnI2

2. Market Value Realised Value (MVRV) Z-Score

MVRV = Market Value - Realised Value (i.e. the last on-chain price of BTC).

The Z-Score is currently at 3, below 6 (last cycle peak) & 7 (historical high).

This metric suggests there's still room to run this cycle. https://t.co/Sw9POgDhqw

1. Net Unrealised Profit/Loss (NUPL)

The NUPL ratio increases when investors who bought BTC at a lower cost basis hold, despite rising prices.

NUPL is now at ~60%, nearing the historical peak of 70%. https://t.co/hEHn4TLTle

Given these catalysts, Grayscale asserts that we're in the "mid-phase" of the bull market (likened to the "5th inning" in baseball).

Here are some of the key metrics they use to support this analysis.üëá

‚Ä¢ BTC outflows.

Outflows are sitting at ~12% of BTC's circulating supply, the lowest in 5 years. This indicates:

‚Ä¢ Investor confidence in BTC's value is rising
‚Ä¢ Preference for HODLing > Selling https://t.co/jUX1URySI1

‚Ä¢ DeFi TVL

Total value locked in DeFi has more than doubled since 2023.

This signals growing user engagement, increased liquidity and smoother DeFi UX. https://t.co/MqVNZWOqQm

‚Ä¢ Stablecoin inflows

Stablecoin supply on CEXs & DEXs has increased by ~6% between Feb & March.

Increased stablecoin liquidity = more capital readily available for trading. https://t.co/sY51axWAVg

2. Healthy on-chain Fundamentals

Grayscale studied 3 key on-chain metrics:

‚Ä¢ Stablecoin inflows
‚Ä¢ DeFi TVL
‚Ä¢ BTC outflows from exchanges

Let's dive deeper into how these metrics impact the bull run.üëá

1. Spot Bitcoin ETF Inflows

With almost a decade of pent-up retail demand, over $12 billion has now flowed into bitcoin ETFs in just 3 months.

ETF inflows have been steadily higher than BTC issuance (now at 3x).

Demand > Supply = upward price pressure. https://t.co/47H8ncote0

But in order to work out how long this rally will sustain, we must assert the underlying price drivers.

They highlight two specifically:

‚Ä¢ Spot Bitcoin ETF inflows
‚Ä¢ Strong on-chain fundamentals

Let's break these down even further.

Grayscale began by citing a number of signals that we're currently in the middle of a bull market.

‚Ä¢ Bitcoin‚Äôs price breaching its ATH prior the Halving
‚Ä¢ Total crypto market cap reaching its previous high
‚Ä¢ Meme coins garnering TradFi attention https://t.co/pt0Kzc7S7S

Grayscale believes we're currently in the ‚ÄúMIDDLE‚Äù stages of a crypto bull run.

They just released a report which breaks down their key findings, AND what comes next.

I read through its 2400 words, so you don't have to.

Nonetheless, it'd be prudent to tread with caution if this trend accelerates.

If we see prominent figures like Justin Bieber, Eminem etc. starting to get into crypto again - that's probably a sign that the end is near.

I can handle Caitlyn and Iggy for now.

Back in 2021, it wasn't like that.

We were in the throws of a full-blown altcoin season.

So to come to any concrete assertions based on such a limited dataset probably isn't wise.

I do believe there is a slight disconnect from the general crypto market, and the meme coin market right now.

The general crypto market (aside from Bitcoin) isn't extremely bullish.

The meme coin sector is extremely bullish (relatively speaking).

Aside from fundamentals - what about prices? Do influxes of celebrities in crypto typically mark local tops?

Well, the previous 2 occasions where we've seen this phenomenon - the market hasn't topped right away, but shortly after, proceeding one final upwards thrust.

But the cons are arguably more obvious: Industry credibility and legitimacy degradation, wrecking new users who may never come back, and undermining the work of good actors who are genuinely using blockchain technology for good.

Meme coins are another beneficiary.

The increased user/liquidity flow into the meme sector is a bonus.

I believe this liquidity eventually works its way back into the established memes - and the overall mindshare establishment of the meme coin narrative.

I think it's inherently bullish for blockchains like Solana, which are a major beneficiary of the increased mindshare/traffic.

It has become the go-to meme coin casino, and the amount of SOL wallets are only going to increase as a result of this craze.
Let's firstly touch on 2 of the crypto sectors where it's a clear tailwind: Solana and meme coins.

So, those are my thoughts on the celebrity meme coin craze, and its pros/cons.

But there's one question left - is this historically a top signal?

Is it intrinsically bullish or bearish for prices?
I have nothing against a celebrity that's genuinely using blockchain tech to provide value. Unfortunately, that's not what recent events would suggest.
An industry we can can weed out the bad actors (by showing our public disdain for some), whilst providing positive feedback and guidance to the good ones.

But the reality is - this is an open market.

If the celebrity meme coin game is going to happen regardless, having trusted figures to help onboard/guide them is better than leaving it in the hands of bad actors.

As I mentioned earlier, crypto users aren't created equal.

1 true $BTC believer and 1 celebrity meme coin tourist are miles apart value-wise.

If the latter gets burnt (and complains to their friends) - the latter can become just as reflexively bad as the BTC bull is good.

Now I'm not denying meme culture has a place, in fact, it can be an amazing on-boarder of new retail.

But is their first taste of crypto being a celebrity meme coin pump and dump REALLY going to make them stick around?

Is that what adoption looks like?
This tweet also highlights the associated negatives with celebrity involvement in crypto.

Then there's the obvious argument of legitimacy.

We're trying to be seen as a space that has evolved from the 2017-ICO clownery and 2021 rugs.

But, when crypto is viewed by the masses as a sector rife with exploitation and greed, it reflects badly.
There's no better way to invite that scrutiny than having some of society's most well-known figures using blockchain technology to grift an extra few thousand bucks.

On the question of where retail will trade, I still think the lowest point of friction are centralised exchanges, and it's likely to remain this way. 

So naturally, the more established memes with CEX listings will perform better - but it will also create a secondary market of speculation where people punt on the "next listing".

In terms of why we aren't euphoric, despite Bitcoin sitting around $60k - it's simple: Altcoins have been in a downtrend for 6 months, and most retail aren't bitcoin maxis - they're looking for quick, easy money in alts. It's probably going to take a break of BTC ATHs to reinvigorate the altcoin market. 

But the good news is, we have seen alts respond well whenever BTC makes a move - so I'm confident it's coming, it's just a game of patience until then.

@KamazXBT If you're savvy, memes are still the highest upside sector.

So in conclusion, yes - retail is (mostly) gone.

There are valid reasons why, and this cycle is fundamentally different because of them.

But it won't take much for retail to return.

And that day may be sooner than you think.
This is a great post by @alpha_pls, which highlights how we tend to overestimate short term progress, but vastly underestimate long term progress.

Infrastructure has significantly improved since 2021 (despite lower prices).

I'm hopeful that this will facilitate the creation of some killer dApps.

Crypto only really needs 2-3 to take off in order to facilitate wide spread adoption.

4. New (and REAL) crypto use cases.

The last 3 points focus mostly on speculation THIS cycle.

But for crypto to truly be sustainable longer term, we need stronger use cases to emerge.

AI, gaming, DeFi all seem like obvious candidates - but they are yet to find their footing.

3. Pareto principle.

As aforementioned, 80% of gains in a bull market come in the last 20%, of the move.

Retail joins the party late.

We simply may just be too early (in terms of cycle duration we comparatively still are).

Some bonus tips: 

‚Ä¢ Curated Twitter lists to cut through the noise

None of these take long, but are extremely high leverage.

A few months ago, it was looking like an extremely accelerated cycle - potentially peaking in Q4 this year.

Now, after recent price action, I'm thinking Q1/Q2 2025 is more realistic.

This last month has set the cycle back & bought us time.

Use it to your advantage.

Your interest in crypto should reflexively move INVERSE to prices (when there's a clear macro trend - like we have now). 

Not the other way around.

Step 4: Use funding rates to gauge market sentiment.

We're far from euphoria at the moment, but funding rates can remain elevated for some time.

When the heat map turns orange and rates soar, that's the signal to lock in profits.

Step 3: Bid HTF levels on altcoins.

Don't just ape blindly.

There will be dips along the way, as seen during Q4 last year when the market started heating up.

Set limit orders at key HTF support levels, or subsequently start bidding spot around those levels.

Step 2: Set up your watchlists.

When the market starts heating up, it's crucial to have a watchlist on TradingView prepared with all the leading altcoins, categorised by the sectors you are bullish on.

Here are mine, but you should also create your own.

Retail don't come back for no reason.

Retail come back because they see others making money.

In the last few weeks alone they've witnessed:

‚Ä¢ A huge Hyperliquid airdrop
‚Ä¢ People making millions on memes
‚Ä¢ $XRP & $ADA pumping again
‚Ä¢ $BTC rocketing to $100k

Perfect storm.

You should never think of the market in absolutes.

You can never be 100% certain of any outcome.

Your positioning should be dictated by probabilities (+EV or -EV).

So let's lay out the pros and cons for $BTC right now, then you decide whether you're bullish at $97k or not.

Pros (bullish):

‚Ä¢ December is historically best month in election years
‚Ä¢ For the S&P, no month is more likely to be higher than December in an election year (83.3%)
‚Ä¢ Equities still making new highs
‚Ä¢ Trump inauguration on Jan 20th
‚Ä¢ Lots of sidelined capital still waiting for an entry (from both the institutional and the retail side)
‚Ä¢ #Bitcoin compressed for 8 months in a tight range, now in an expansion phase
‚Ä¢ We're still generally following past cycles, and are now entering the most aggressive expansionary phase

Cons (bearish):

‚Ä¢ 100k psychological resistance

If you want to ‚Äúsucceed‚Äù in business/life, the most important prerequisite is to truly understand yourself.

Your strengths, your weaknesses, your flaws.

Self-introspection is the only way to break past your limits.

I have realised many of my weaknesses are actually super powers, and vice versa.

i.e. my impulsivity & obsessiveness. Powerful tools when harnessed, but these traits can also break you if you let them take control.

You need to structure your life to allow your strengths to thrive, whilst minimising the negative impacts of your weaknesses. I‚Äôm still working on doing this, but I feel like I‚Äôve made great progress over the past year.

Obviously seeing a psychologist to assist with this stuff is greatly beneficial (even if you don‚Äôt have a ‚Äúproblem‚Äù). But if you‚Äôre shy, or just want to kick off the process in a frictionless way - brain dumping into ChatGPT and getting some feedback can actually be quite insightful/therapeutic. Remember, the more information you feed it - the more capable it is. But I still recommend reflecting with an actual human in tandem.

Getting rich, achieving ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù - whatever that is to you, is more of a reflection of how you‚Äôre able to maneuver your own psychology, as opposed to get-rich gimmicks. Knowledge is power, but only if you know how to apply it effectively to your own life.

5. Opportunity cost

One of the most powerful ways to reassess your portfolio is by asking:

If this position were magically converted to fiat overnight - would I buy it back at the current price?

If not, why are you still holding it?

This mental reset strips away attachment and forces clarity on capital efficiency.

Further examples:

‚Ä¢ Parking capital in stagnant assets with no volatility or catalysts incurs hidden costs (that liquidity could be rotated into higher-conviction, higher-upside setups).

‚Ä¢ Holding drawdowns (sunk cost fallacy) a double loss - you‚Äôre bleeding time and sidelining capital that could be compounding elsewhere with momentum and narrative alignment.

It's equally (if not more) important to look at where you're NOT allocated, vs where you are currently allocated.

4. First principles thinking

This is essentially a method of problem-solving that involves breaking down complex issues into their most basic and fundamental parts.

When investing long-term, ask yourself if the root fundamentals make sense (instead of chasing narratives/buzzwords).

 ‚Ä¢ What problem does it solve?
 ‚Ä¢ Is the token necessary?
 ‚Ä¢ Are the incentives sustainable?

3. Asymmetric risk/reward

Limit downside, and let the upside take care of itself.

The best plays are those where you don't lose much when you're wrong, but win big when you‚Äôre right.

A simple way of implementing this is by enforcing max drawdown/invalidation parameters, evaluating R/R on your trades. Know exactly where your idea breaks (price, time, or narrative).

Most of the top traders I know are extremely quick to cut a bad position, and don't let their ego get in the way of doing so.

2. Compounding wins

You don‚Äôt need to catch every market move.

You just need to stack small, repeatable wins and avoid blowups.

Most people chase 10x trades and end up back at zero.

The best traders I know (like @gametheorizing) are extremely disciplined, and focus on compounding wealth over time via a series of smaller bets.

Success in crypto is ultimately a function of survival.

Focus on staying in the game long enough to let compounding do the heavy lifting.

1. Thinking in bets

Treat every trade or investment as a probability-based decision.

You can theoretically do everything right and still lose - what matters is the process itself, not the outcome. https://t.co/YwcdUg8f4h

Portfolio strategy that has worked well for many of my friends in the space: Sit 100% in stables, and take individual bets when opportunities arise.

Essentially, treating stables as your default position, and any altcoin trade as a deviation away from that position.

It's not the right strategy for everyone, and you do need skill to manage the entries/exits of your active positions - but i've seen it work many times.

Pros:
‚Ä¢ No downside risk (minus inflation/opportunity cost)
‚Ä¢ Liquidity to take advantage of big drawdowns whilst others panic
‚Ä¢ Less emotion
‚Ä¢ Leverage to go big when the stars align on a trade

Cons:
‚Ä¢ Rules out long-term fundamental investing (where I have historically done well, alongside many others)
‚Ä¢ Requires a higher degree of skill with your active trades
‚Ä¢ Opportunity cost/risk of being caught off-side (slightly mitigated by the fact that in an uptrend, you're likely trading bullish continuation anyway)

Currently, I am doing a 50/50 split. 50% long term, 50% stables (this strategy). That's where I am most comfortable, and what aligns the best with my temperament. The best strategy is the one which aligns with your own skills/pitfalls.

Playbook to (actually) succeeding in crypto long term:

1. Develop an edge (easiest ones are info/speed/patience/risk management or a mix of multiple - for those with time, info/speed are best imo)

2. Make a series of high-conviction, yet diligently weighted bets across multiple time frames

3. Religiously take profits into stables/BTC

4. Use said profits to reinvest into either your business (which generates cash flow), or cash flow generating assets

Thought I'd give my thoughts on "escaping the rat race" without quitting your job..

1. Your #1 goal is skill acquisition (right now the most asymmetric upside is in AI/crypto/digital products imo). Focus on building skills, not making money. The money comes as a result of getting really good at something.

2. Weekends are your best friend - don't quit your day job, as it's hard to build a proper business from a position of defence. Utilise gaps in your time (i.e. weekends and time after/before work to chip away at point #1).

3. Pick your sacrifice - more time focusing on skill acquisition/business naturally detracts from other areas like friends/family/hobbies. Balance is ultimately important, but something has to give if you're serious about "escaping" - at least in the short term.

4. Be realistic: Escaping the "rat race" is more likely to come from consistently stacking smaller wins/compounding wealth over time, as opposed to hitting a huge trade or business idea. Time is both your biggest enemy and best friend here.

Just make sure before you enter a coin, you've clearly defined where it sits in your overall portfolio strategy.

This is mine.

The 50/50 split I use for my crypto portfolio at this stage in the cycle:

50% in long-term investments: Think $BTC, $ETH, $SOL, $HYPE etc. Will still look to TP a decent % on these as prices head into mania territory, but with the idea of being exposed longer term (multi-year).

50% in short-mid term swing investments: Mainly altcoins that are narratively aligned with the market, and are exhibiting relative strength, + some low-cap punts that could pay off in the right environment. I'm much more "ruthless" with this section of my portfolio (i.e., cutting on weakness, tweaking portfolio based on opportunity cost), as I'm under no illusions that most of these coins will go to 0 and never come back. That's my base case at least, if I'm proven wrong - great. Sometimes I'm heavier in cash with this portion of my portfolio, sometimes I'm more heavily invested - it depends on where we are in the cycle.

Bonus: You can also have "sub weightings" for a position. Take BTC for example: You could have 50% that you hold long term, and 50% in your short-term to mid-term portfolio that you swing trade based on strength. The key is making this dissection very clear in your portfolio - I recommend using separate wallets/coin trackers for both: tagged "short term" and "long term".

Most people f*ck up because they mix and mash all their holdings in one, without a clear plan for each holding.

(excluding stablecoin weighting - which oscillates between 30-50% depending on if I have active trades open)

I share my opinions. 

They may be right, they may be wrong. 

What I deem to be probabilistic may or may not be probabilistic to someone else. 

The whole point of content creation is to observe things, share those observations, and it's up to the audience to decide how they'd like to use that information.

Here's the (uncomfortable) truth about crypto. 

No one on this app has a f*cking clue what happens next.

This includes GCR, Ansem, Capo, Kang, or any of the other 1000 traders flooding your timeline. 

The cycle top could be already in, or maybe it's later this year, or in 2025, or even in 2026. Or maybe we aren't even in a cycle.

Bitcoin may go to $100k this year, it may not, or it may go to $40k before it does.

No one knows. And I mean no one. No matter what they claim.

But this doesn't matter.

Your goal as a trader/investor is to interpret market changes, digest new information to the best of your ability, and manage risk accordingly.

Just make sure you follow these 4 principles: 

1. Stay vigilant. 

Those who are quick to adapt to changing conditions/process new information typically come out ahead. 

2. Don't go all in on a single thesis. 

This market doesn't owe you anything. Your bias doesn't matter. Always have a plan B if plan A doesn't pan out. And have a plan C for plan B.

3. Be wary of "consensus" trades. 

When the whole TL is bullish, that's probably time to take profits. And conversely, when the entire TL is screaming for lower - that's probably the time to buy. Popular sentiment if more often a counter signal, than it is correct.

And MOST importantly:

4. Never put too much weight on a single trader's thesis. 

Take the information in, analyse it, acknowledge it - but don't let it solely drive decision making. Otherwise you'll be flip flopping daily. And even if your initial bias was right, your portfolio won't reflect it.

It's good to have a thesis - but find that balance between being too flexible and too ridged.

@blknoiz06 Good advice.

99% of projects don't actually NEED a token. 

Study Base, Arbitrum, LayerZero & Wormhole (before token launch) etc.

All amazing products - all fully functioning with no token (Base still is, and thriving). 

But let me add more nuance.üëá

There are obvious arguments FOR having a token (decentralisation, governance, bootstrapping, liquidity, community building etc.)

And these are no doubt important factors.

But the reality is, and this is important to understand from a retail POV, these factors usually come secondary to the underlying principle that it's much easier to raise capital/extract profits vs traditional revenue models.

And many crypto products wouldn't be able to raise (and thus build) in the first place if it weren't for this dynamic (as these businesses simply wouldn't be profitable enough on revenue alone).

So do these products NEED tokens to function? No. 

But does the industry rely on new tokens to innovate? Yes.

Obvious downsides are: Private > public market arb (retail extraction), token dilution, liquidity fragmentation etc.

But the obvious pro is: More innovation, as teams are able to raise capital to build, and devs are incentivised to develop new products/dApps.

I'd love to see more infrastructure products introducing more interesting/dynamic token utility - like we've seen across the DeFi market. I suppose regulation etc. does slightly limit this, however - but at a cost to value accrual.

It's certainly an interesting discussion, and I'd love to hear your thoughts below.

Remember, VCs are usually locked for years. 

So they realistically need a minimum 3-5x+ on their initial investment to justify the opportunity cost of locking capital. 

Otherwise they could literally just ride $BTC spot and chill.

The days of easy VC wins are over.

For many new tokens, buying in the liquid market is a MUCH better deal than private.

This recent dip has been a bit of a wake up call to not get too greedy.

It's easy to get complacent when it comes to selling when prices are pumping.

But the dips are when you're made to pay.

Next year, make a habit out of taking profits on rips. You won't regret it.

The weird thing about crypto is that effort and results aren't correlated (in the short term).

Sometimes when I try too hard, I end up over-trading.

Conversely, some of my best trades have fallen in my lap.

But, by showing up every day, you compound your chances of success.

There's this misconception in crypto that every trade needs to be a winner.

This is far from the truth.

If you invest in 10 coins, and 8 go to 0 (but two 10x), you've doubled your money. One 10x and you break even.

That's the beauty of this game. You don't always need to be right, you just need to be right often enough to make money.

The implications are still fresh, and as more information comes out, we will likely get more clarity.

Yet, despite the clear longer-term bullish implications, the AI crypto market is still experiencing short-term downside, following NVIDIA's lead.

I think this dip is creating great opportunities to scoop up quality projects at discounts.

The good thing about AI in crypto, and the reason I think it actually BENEFITS from new launches like R-1, is because it can leverage ALL models, with better models accelerating the development of high-quality agents and agentic enterprises.
DeepSeek specifically will also shift value accrual from the compute layer to the agents built on top by reducing computational costs.

AI agents are a very powerful onboarding tool for Web3, as they simplify an otherwise complex user experience.

As these agents harness better models, the end result will be even smoother and more functional use cases.

There is another major beneficiary of this: AI crypto.

Despite also falling victim to the broader market selloff, decentralised AI protocols clearly stand to benefit.

Lower costs = more scalable and profitable business models.

But, ultimately, I think it's great for the consumer.

Lower cost AI models democratise access to AI technology by making it cheaper to consume.
The DeepSeek story/reaction is a fascinating one, as it highlights how critical the battle for AI dominance will be in terms of winning the global one.

Risk assets like crypto also sold off in anticipation of a weak US open, with the sell-off being compounded by the looming FOMC interest rate decision in 2 days, which was already resulting in some de-risking.

And because NVIDIA has been such a strong gainer and contributed to the majority of the Nasdaq index's recent rise, it makes sense that the sell-off is equally reflexive to the downside when it retraces.

Well, if DeepSeek was able to develop BETTER AI with WEAKER chips, then this fundamentally affects NVIDIA's business model.

Energy-intensive models require better hardware, where NVIDIA is the market leader.

But if the trend moves towards more energy-efficient models, this could impact NVIDIA's bottom line.

But even though there are still question marks, one thing is for sure: It has spooked US investors.

$NVIDIA shares plummeted -21% for the day, and over a trillion dollars was wiped off US tech stock valuations.

But why?
Elon Musk has also weighed in on the debate, noting that DeepSeek "obviously" has about 50,000 Nvidia H100 chips that can't be mentioned due to US export controls.

But, there has been some skepticism as to the legitimacy of these claims.

Was it really developed in under 2 months? Is it really as energy efficient as they claim?

We don't know for sure, and the skepticism is justified.
To add fuel to the fire, DeepSeek just released another open-source AI model, Janus-Pro-7B, which currently outperforms OpenAI's DALL-E 3 across multiple benchmarks.

And, it's reportedly 93% less energy intensive than ChatGPT's o1 model.

Making it the most efficient AI LLM model on the planet.
But, the mind-blowing part is that despite the small budget and short development time, it actually outperforms OpenAI's ChatGPT across a variety of benchmarks.
Post-launch, it quickly flipped ChatGPT to become the number one app in the App Store in both the US and China.
This is compared to the hundreds of millions or billions of dollars US companies spend on their AI technologies, which often take years to develop.

Hear me out (this is important):

For 6 months straight (between October 2023 and March 2024), altcoins rallied hard. Many alts rose 4-5x off their floors, and coins from hot sectors (like AI and memes) did a 10-15x during this time.

BUT.

IT WASN'T UNTIL FEBRUARY that retail interest really started to come back (this is evidenced via the google trends, app store rankings, YT views etc.)

Think about that..

Months and months of prices pumping, yet they didn't come back until.. the FINAL month of the pump?

Just like in other areas of life, the Pareto Principle also applies to crypto.

80% of the gains (and subsequently 80% of the retail interest in crypto) occur during the FINAL 20% of the move.

Retail literally won't blink an eye until things have already been taking off for months.

This current move (in alts) has only lasted 4 weeks - after a 6 month downtrend.

Last time, it took them 5 whole months to finally pay attention. The same is likely to happen again (albeit due to the trust the March rally built - it will take slightly less long this time around).

This gives you a big opportunity to position yourself before the crowd comes.

Ultimately, $BTC breaking ATHs is great marketing for the space, and the wealth effect from a BTC rally will likely see alts go way higher.

Just don't be surprised if it takes some extra time for your taxi driver to finally take notice.

Additionally, the base layer i.e blockchains weren't performant enough to support the 1000s of TPS necessary for social media.

‚Ä¢ A complicated sign-up process (steep curve to onboarding)

‚Ä¢ Slow release of features and upgrades (was outdated quickly)

Mastodon aimed to be the largest decentralised social media network with microblogging features like X/Twitter.

However, their UX didn't deliver on that promise.

1. BitClout created profiles/tokens for celebs without their consent.

BitClout allowed users to monetise their profiles with 'Creator Coins' that represent a stake in the creator's journey.

Users could buy, sell & trade these tokens.

Sector leaders.

Since the fall of FTX, only 8 coins have broken their previous ATH vs $BTC.

This stat shocked me when I first read it.

But the more I think about it - the more it makes sense. 

A few important takeaways (that can help you maximise this cycle): 

1. Asset selection is crucial this cycle. Moreso than ever. Until (and if) there's a retail liquidity injection event, it's likely that we keep experiencing specific sector outperformance. 

Last bull run, you could basically bet on anything and beat $BTC.

This cycle, you've been punished for being overexposed to certain sectors (L2, gaming etc.) - and rewarded for being exposed to others (memes, AI, RWA).

Crypto is an attention economy. The money flows where attention goes. 

Keep this in mind when constructing your portfolio. Even the best tech won't perform (price wise) if there is no compelling reason to buy.

2. We're seeing ATH dilution. Thousands of new launches per day, low float/high FDV VC coins launching in the billions. With this much dilution - no wonder many alts are struggling to perform. 

New launches are outpacing new liquidity coming in. 

I'm currently focusing on: 

‚Ä¢ <$1b FDV alts that have released most of their supply, and have a strong product/narrative/mindshare in their respective niche. I think over the coming months you'll notice a trend of these "older" coins performing well. 

‚Ä¢ Alts that are leading and price-responsive to pumps within leading sectors (memes, AI, RWA thus far - and in the future, select L1s/strong ecosystems). 

‚Ä¢ Alts that have launched significantly under (my perceived) fair value, yet have minimal unlocks during year 1 (more of a short-mid term play).

3. This entire bull run (thus far) has been let by #Bitcoin, and more specifically, the spot ETF narrative. Considering this, it's no surprise alts have been underperforming. Aside from memes and a select couple of sectors, most alts have hardly pumped yet (for the reasons mentioned above). 

This, in my opinion, is actually a bullish thing. More room to play catch up + BTC leading has been an instrumental part of each prior bull run. 

But for a true alt season, we will need additional catalysts. Whether that be sector driven or macro driven (more likely).

Tbh - if you're a savvy trader and good at spotting rotations/positioning, there is still insane money to be made even without the face-melting alt season we all crave.

Many of my friends in the space (myself included) have had record quarters this year even in mildly bullish conditions for most alts.

This isn't to brag, but to remind you that the hustle can really pay off in the right environment - and it doesn't take long to bear the financial fruits of such labour. 

All you need is 1-2 strong months per year, and protect your capital during the rest.

On the 16th of June, BlackRock applied for a spot #Bitcoin spot ETF.

Many had tried and failed in the past, but this time was different.

As now, the world's largest asset manager (with an exemplary ETF approval record) had come to the party.

However, despite all the pain, at some point, a major shift in sentiment began to occur.

Although prices had started to move off the floor in Jan 2023, one moment later in the year changed everything.

Only a select few chose to stay (many of you are likely reading this thread right now).

This is all important context to understand my conclusions later in the thread, as to why this cycle is very different from others.

If you were burnt financially, you left.

If you weren't burnt financially, you still left (price/time capitulation)

And if you never invested a cent in crypto, you'd likely think the industry is a complete scam, reading the thousands of preposterous headlines.
It doesn't take a mathematician to postulate the sheer damage this would have on the industry, and its reputation.

2021 exposed the most amount of people EVER to crypto.

Crypto was everywhere. On football stadiums, national television, celebrity IGs, and all over your feed.

2022 exposed those same new entrants to the biggest losses EVER in crypto.

This includes the collapse of:

‚Ä¢¬†3AC (crypto's biggest VC at the time)
‚Ä¢¬†Celsius
‚Ä¢¬†BlockFi
‚Ä¢¬†Voyager

And of course, the infamous FTX, one of crypto's biggest, and at the time, most trusted, crypto exchanges.
Unfortunately, this pain would be further amplified by a raft of contagion - fueled by LUNA's collapse (and dubious business practices from a plethora of bad actors).

In a matter of days, $45 billion was wiped off the market, further causing hundreds of billions in losses in the larger crypto market.

Many retail investors got their first taste of the real underlying risk of crypto (and investing in general).

Crypto technically topped in November 2021.

But it wasn't until May 2022 that crypto would be delivered its final death blow: The LUNA & UST collapse.

Crypto is an extremely reflexive asset class, meaning that the higher prices go, the more attention is driven to the market, fueling further price rises.

It's this effect that creates so much opportunity in the market.

But also, how retail loses money.

But, as bubbles always do, it ended badly.

You have to remember that 80% of gains happen in the last 20% of a cycle (time wise).

It's also in that last 20% that retail pour into the market.

Although #Bitcoin was a strong performer, altcoins took centre stage.

Coins like $SOL, $FTM, $AVAX and $LUNA all pulled 500x+ multiples.

Asset selection wasn't even that important, you could've basically longed any coin and made a quick buck.

2021 was an explosive year for crypto.

From March 2020 until November 2021, the crypto market rallied 2,672%, with many alts pulling 50-100x+ multiples.

It was a perfect storm of unprecedented money printing, stimulus, and people locked (and bored) at home. https://t.co/0LNQNd5Si4

To be a successful trader/investor, it's critical that you understand your limits, and what's sustainable for you.

If you work a 9-to-5 job, intra-day scalping isn't sustainable; it's better to pick an H4 or D1 strategy for your entries.

If you're a fundamental investor, it's best to focus on long-term trends and position during quiet periods, as opposed to hopping on every new hot rotation.

The key to succeeding in markets is staying in the game. And for that, you need a sustainable strategy.

It's the same with the gym. If you want a good physique, but you're time limited, it's better to be consistent with a 3-day/week split than inconsistent with a bro split.

Consistency trumps all.

Hopefully I was able to make some sense of what's been occurring lately, for those that have been confused about recent price action.

Dispersion isn't the only problem, but it certainly is a major one - and something that needs to be discussed.

The market needs to give retail a reason to come back. This, at least, fixes one half of the problem.

Whether it be a a $BTC pump, $ETH ETF, macro shift, or killer apps that people actually want to use.

There are lots of potential catalysts out there.

Also, on the exchange side, I'd also like to see exchanges be more pragmatic.

One way to offset the insane amount of new listings/dilution, is to be equally ruthless with delistings.

Let's flush out the 10,000 dead projects that are still soaking up valuable liquidity.

At the end of the day, a more retail-friendly market bodes well for everyone.

The projects, the VCs, and the exchanges.

More users is good for everyone.

Most of the current issues are a symptom of short-sightedness (and the nascency of the industry).

Even if the insiders don't enforce change, the market eventually will.

The market will always self correct and adjust, with the diminishing efficacy of the current meta + public response likely to sway things in the future.

‚Ä¢ Exchanges could enforce better token distribution
‚Ä¢ Teams could prioritise community allocation & bigger pools for genuine users
‚Ä¢ Higher % could be unlocked on launch (potentially implementing measures like laddered sell taxes etc. to disincentive dumping).

I don't have all the answers to this problem.

It's a complex issue and there are many players who could make a difference.

Here are a few ideas, however.

This cycle, tokens launch at $5b, $10b, $20b+ and leave no room for price discovery in the open market.

And then they bleed, bleed, and bleed as their unlocks start to hit the market.

With price discovery for many of these high FDV coins happening in private markets, retail doesn't have a shot at a 10x, 20x or 50x like the VCs.

In 2021, you could ape a launchpad token and genuinely hit a 100x.

This skew becomes an issue because retail feel like they can't win.

And if they feel like they can't win, they won't play the game.

Why do you think memes have dominated this year?

It's the only meta where retail feels like they have a fighting chance.

Firstly, I must emphasise the need for more liquid funds in crypto.

There are comparatively too many VCs.

The skew towards private market is one of the biggest (and most damaging) issues in crypto, especially compared to other markets like equites and real estate.

Now you know what the issue is, let's discuss the question at hand.

How could things turn around?

I wrote a thread last week on the impact of these unlocks (with data).

If you're interested, check it out below.

However, it's not. So we find ourselves in the situation of:

A) Not enough new liquidity entering the market, and
B) An insane amount of dilution/sell pressure from unlocks

All of these new launches and supply would be fine and dandy if new liquidity was entering the market.

In 2021, there were hundreds of new launches per day - and everything was up only.

And it's not only the volume of tokens launching that is a problem.

The low FDV/high float mechanics of many of these new launches is a big issue.

It leads to a) a high degree of dispersion, and b) constant supply pressure.

It's the exact same in crypto.

If you print more tokens, this, in turn, reduces crypto's purchasing power relative to other currencies (like USD).

Altcoin dispersion is basically crypto's version of inflation.

Think of token dilution as inflation.

If the government prints USD, this, in turn, reduces USD's purchasing power relative to the cost of goods and services.

The biggest mistake people make is trying to position themselves for every micro move.

Everyone speaks about how to make money in a bull run, but I think an equally valid discussion is how to successfully exit.

I've thought a lot about this and I have a rough plan.

1. DCA out progressively as prices climb (I won't time the top but I'm ok with that). I've already started shifting money out of crypto slowly (I'm still trying to maintain adequate exposure as I still have a bullish disposition heading into 2025, but I've taken out enough not to need to worry about financial security in the event of a black swan).

2. When a big collapse does come, and this may not be until the end of 2025/2026 (who knows, that's why you ladder out progressively), I'll have parked capital in "safe assets" with the goal of a) capital preservation, and b) income production. This will be a mix of:

‚Ä¢ US treasuries (basically cash but with higher yield to cover inflation). Probably some other currencies too just to hedge FX.
‚Ä¢ Gold (historically it holds up much better during times of uncertainty than #Bitcoin).
‚Ä¢ Real estate (this will also drop in a market collapse, but no where near as violently as equities and its income producing - but it's better to do this sooner as R/R will get worse as the economic cycle progresses, as real estate prices typically lag more liquid assets).

3 (this is the most lucrative step). Buy back a ton of $BTC and equities during the inevitable market collapse (potentially 2026-2027). Also invest in new startups (many of which will likely be in web3) during this period when valuations are low, with an AI focus (that's the first bubble that will probably pop in a market crash but still offers immense long term upside).

The ultimate goal is to have firepower during an economic collapse, that's how you significantly speed up long term wealth creation. It's also impossible to time, so taking an extremely macro lens when making these decisions is needed.

I'd also love to hear your plans too (including all the giga brains out there), as I'm always open to optimising my strategy).

If you find out about a coin (but it's already pumped hard) - add it to your watchlist, sit on it for a few days, and if you're still bullish, accumulate on the next big dip.

Don't just ape instantly.

A good token at a bad price is a bad buy.
A bad token at a good price is a good buy.

6. @0xfluid - $FLUID

Fluid captures stablecoin growth by optimizing their use in lending and liquidity aggregation.

It consolidates liquidity across DeFi ‚Äúmoney legos‚Äù into a unified layer, offering high-yield lending opportunities for stablecoins like USDC & USDT, thus attracting more stablecoin inflows.

5. @pendle_fi - $PENDLE

Pendle captures stablecoin growth by creating a yield market that directly integrates stablecoins and their derivatives.

It splits yield-bearing assets into Principal Tokens (PT) and Yield Tokens (YT).

This lets users speculate on or hedge against stablecoin yields, which are a massive driver of DeFi activity.

4. @CurveFinance - $CRV

CRV is the home of stablecoin liquidity.

It also has its own native over-collateralised stablecoin, $crvUSD.

CRV (specifically veCRV lockers) earn trading fees from their liquidity pools.

If stablecoin trading volume grows, so do CRV rewards.

3. @aave - $AAVE

Aave is a money market where users borrow and lend assets (stables are the most borrowed).

They recently launched their own over-collateralised stable, $GHO.

AAVE holders benefit as stablecoin demand drives lending fees. GHO‚Äôs interest payments funnel to Aave DAO.

Basically, AAVE is a proxy bet on stablecoin lending demand.

2. MakerDAO - $MKR

They're the issuer of $DAI, the original decentralised stablecoin.

MKR holders gain from DAI's growth through stability fees. More DAI demand can trigger MKR buybacks and burns.

As USDe‚Äôs circulating supply grows, the protocol‚Äôs revenue scales accordingly.

They are also launching their own blockchain in collaboration with Securitize, and are focused on the continued expansion of USDe.

In terms of altcoin bets, $ENA is one of the most obvious stablecoin proxies.

1. @ethena_labs - $ENA

Ethena's stablecoin, USDe, accounts for 2.3% of the total stablecoin market.

They generate revenue via a unique mechanism of backing USDe, a synthetic dollar, with delta-hedged positions on staked Ethereum (e.g., stETH) and short perpetual futures contracts.

2. Major L1s (Ethereum, Solana & Tron).

But if stablecoin volumes continue to grow, the L1s with the most adoption benefit through increased fee generation.

1. @coinbase ( $COIN )

4. Stablecoins = DeFi‚Äôs dollar.

Stables essentially power the on-chain economy.

They are integral in lending, yield farming, and DEX trading.

Want a loan? You borrow stables. Yield farming? You earn in stables.

Current estimates suggest there is around $150m-$200m of new supply pressure per day.

This constant sell pressure takes a huge toll on the market.

The more tokens that launch, the more cumulative supply pressure on the market.

And this supply pressure "stacks".

Many projects from 2021 are still unlocking, with supply "stacking" across every subsequent year (2022, 2023, 2024).

This is a big problem. And is one of the major reasons why crypto has been struggling this year, despite $BTC hitting new ATHs.

Why?
We now have 5.7 times the amount of crypto tokens than we did during peak bull in 2021. https://t.co/OQqTxjNNFr

You could argue that these numbers are inflated by the ease of deploying a meme on-chain.

And that's true, yes.

But it's still an insane figure.

For a more accurate number, see the image below from CoinGecko, which excludes many of the smaller memes.

Here are the stats. They're crazy.

Over 1 million new crypto tokens have been launched since April alone.

(half of which are meme coins created on the Solana network). https://t.co/7Yeffv9Aa6

And it wasn't just the OLD projects deciding to launch.

Many new players saw the new bullish conditions as an opportunity to launch a project and make a quick buck.

As a result, 2024 has seen a historic number of new launches.

After months and months of delaying, they could FINALLY launch their tokens in better conditions.

So they did.

It started with one.

And another, and another, and another.

It took a while, but eventually - in Q4 2023, they got it.

(remember, the biggest spike in VC funding was in Q1 2022, 18 months prior). https://t.co/JjTpvE2jQu

Launching a project in the midst of a bear is a death sentence.

Low liquidity + bad sentiment + lack of interest means many new bear market launches were dead on arrival.

So founders decided to wait for a reversal.

So what did the projects do, that raised all that money earlier in the year?

They delayed.

And delayed.

And delayed.

But shortly after, the party stopped.

A cascade of contagion, starting with LUNA, and ending with FTX, completely decimated the market.

The low barriers to entry, combined with the high upside crypto presented in the bull market, made web3 a breeding ground for new startups.

New tokens were popping up left right and centre, resulting in the total crypto token count tripling between 2021-2022.

But remember, VCs are only investors.

Increased deal count volume also comes from an increase in the amount of projects being created.

Interestingly, the largest quarter EVER for VC funding ($12b) was Q1 2022.

This marked the beginning of the bear (yes, VCs timed the top). https://t.co/YUYNd1C4UE
This investment helps fund the project with capital to develop, with VCs also often providing other services/connections to help get a project off the ground.

For those who don't understand private markets, put simply, a VC will invest capital into a project at an early stage (typically 6 months - 2 years prior to launch), at a typically lower valuation (with vesting attached).

During this time, VCs started pouring unprecedented amounts of capital into the space.

Founders & VCs are just like retail - they're opportunists.

The uptick in investment was a natural capitalistic response to market conditions. https://t.co/O4Icd0YYMX

Let me take you back to 2021.

The market was in a frenzy.

New liquidity was rapidly pouring into the market, mainly being driven by fresh retail.

The bull market seemed unstoppable, and risk appetite was at its highest. https://t.co/qyHZFFclPO

The objective of this thread is to give you more insight into crypto's biggest issue.

It will explain exactly how we got here, why prices are behaving the way they are, and the path forward.

If you're holding an asset, you're locking up capital.

You don't need to be all in to make huge gains in crypto.

@crypto_couple21 @ZssBecker True - I'm not taking this defensively at all. 

I just don't want people to feel dissuaded to start a personal brand when it's something that I've found so valuable in terms of personal growth.

I disagree with this.

Although having a broad skill set is important, you do learn A LOT by being hands on with content (for me it's been invaluable - and would of been a lot harder WITHOUT starting a personal brand).

For example: How social media works, the attention economy, how to convey a message, market a product etc. - and that knowledge is transferable into a raft of other fields whether it be SaaS, product marketing, financial marketing, social media etc.

And that's just on the skill side - not to mention the mental resilience and growth you develop from having to constantly show up and post, stay on top of trends & execute etc. 

Personally, I've learnt so much via growing an online brand. 

And it's opened up many doors to start other ventures both through skills gained + network + financial freedom etc.

Look at Mr. Beast as an example - started purely in content and has become so good at the craft that it's opened doors to 100x other ventures. 

Anyone can do this (of course on a smaller scale) that applies themselves.

I think the bigger issue is doing nothing at all.

No reason why you can't run a personal brand AND build businesses/learn hard skills at the same time. Both go hand in hand. Just don't be naive and assume that "influencing" will pay the bills forever.

AI is going to completely disrupt the crypto industry.

I'm heavily placing my bets.

Regardless of whoever wins the election, one thing is for certain:

Markets hate uncertainty.

There is enough uncertainty right now to deter big players from positioning pre election.

I think we rally either way regardless of outcome.

The election is just 8 days away, and it's going to send shockwaves through the crypto market.

Here's my advice to navigate the coming days.

1. Avoid leverage.

This is going to be a highly volatile period, compounded by lower liquidity as MMs are likely to thin out the books to protect themselves from getting trampled by the herd. It's best to stick to spot until the dust settles post-election. You may see some fantastic buying opportunities in the form of an intra-week/day correction. Take advantage of these.

2. Don't trust the first move.

Even a Trump win could result in an initial dump, before the eventual pump. Don't FOMO into the first sign of directionality. We've seen this many times before with FOMC moves duping people into panic buying/selling.

3. Stick to your plan.

This is going to be a high noise period. Lots of opinions, short term speculation, and volatility. Don't let this cloud your overall strategy. Stick to your pre-defined plan, and capitalise on dips (if there are any).

10. DON‚ÄôT UPGRADE YOUR LIFESTYLE

This is a reminder to myself, as much as it is a message to you.

It can be tempting to upgrade your lifestyle based on paper profits, or the promise of future gains.

But those funds could be put to much better use.

Treat yourself later.

9. DON'T WASTE TIME

Maximising a bull market takes sacrifice. This is especially true for younger people (like me) that don't have as many concrete obligations.

These opportunities don't last forever. Take advantage whilst you can.

8. DON'T QUIT NOW

If you're ever feeling overwhelmed, remember that you've been through the hard part.

You survived a bear market littered with challenges (LUNA, FTX, Voyager, boredom, retail capitulation etc.)

Now isn't the time to give up!

7. DON'T OUTSMART YOURSELF

When retail floods back into the market, they gravitate towards narratives they can easily understand.

They don't want to buy the latest L3 ZK cross-chain interoperability aggregator.

I wrote an entire thread on this concept if you're interested.

6. DON‚ÄôT FADE STRENGTH

One of the most difficult things to comprehend in a bull run is the insane strength the market can exhibit, and how long it can remain irrational.

Long leaders, not laggards.

Don't fight the trend. Submit to it and use it to your advantage.

5. DON'T GET GREEDY

Extreme green days are actually great times to take some gains off the table.

This way you're consistently replenishing your stablecoin balance, allowing you to take advantage of bull market dips.

Dips are your friend, but only if you're prepared.

4. DON'T OVER-ROTATE

This was my biggest mistake in 2021.

When you hit a 10x trade, it can be tempting to roll those profits into other altcoins.

But you're essentially playing a game of hot potato.

Eventually, the market will turn and all your hard work is erased.

3. DON‚ÄôT BLINDLY APE

A little research goes a long way in a bull run.

Look into coins that are showing strength, then apply some DD into their tokenomics/basic fundamentals.

Although hype trumps fundamentals in a bull, DD is still necessary to spot red flags.

2. DON‚ÄôT GO IN WITHOUT A PLAN

Before you buy a coin, always clearly outline your buy plan, as well as your sell plan, with clear invalidation levels.

I wrote a thread last week outlining my full take-profit strategy/exit plan, which you may find valuable.

1. DON'T CHASE PUMPS

This is the easiest way to lose money in an up-trending market.

Every day there is a new coin/narrative which is the new flavour of CT.

Bull market rotations are fickle and are now happening quicker than ever before.

Stick to your thesis and don't flinch.

Making money in a bull run is easy. Keeping it is hard.

In 2021, I could've walked away with millions.

Instead, I round-tripped a lot of my profits.

But you can learn from my mistakes, and do things the RIGHT way.

Markets hate uncertainty. 

It's going to be a very volatile few weeks ahead.

"But Miles, if you knew the market would dip - why wouldn't you short?"

1. Even if I'm 100% certain of a dip, all it takes is your timing to be off by 1-2 days to get wiped on a leverage short.

2. If I'm wary of a pullback, I prefer to spot-sell in order to recapitalise my stablecoin stocks. Spot selling is effectively the same as short selling minus leverage.

3. It's a macro bull market. Unless you're a scalper (which I'm not), positioning short at ANY point is extremely risky as momentum is against you. And the inverse is true for a macro bear market. The trend is your friend until the end of the trend.

"Why is sentiment so bad when $BTC is above $100k?!"

1. Most people hold alts, and the majority (with the exception of AI/some utility/RWA) have underperformed BTC.

2. The constant "alt season" fakeouts are increasing skepticism, and the longer this goes on the less people believe (time vs price based capitulation).

3. There are so many rotations, and unless you're spending hours per day in the space it's almost impossible to keep up with (nor should you feel obligated to - but FOMO is a killer in this industry).

4. Post-inauguration there's no "North Star" for participants to cling onto (this could change at any moment, of course). FOMC is also in 6 days which will shake things up again (for better or worse).

5. (This one is a bit more outlandish - but interesting to consider): I think the rapid development of AI has introduce a time-based FOMO we've never seen before (due to how it will radicalise the labour industry) - and people have a right to be concerned (I think about it almost daily). Time pressure leads to more reliance on external sources (i.e. crypto) to "make it" - and the longer people don't "make it", the more anxiety builds.

There are other reasons too (lack of clear macro direction, reliance on the 4-year cycle theory etc.) but I think these are some of the main ones.

The good news is, there is still a ridiculous amount of opportunity in this market and as we know, things can turn at any moment (look at the last 2 weeks - we've been oscillating from despair to excitement weekly on this app), and a few days of positive price action seems to wipe the memories of most. Just have to stay in the game (do whatever you need to not to get shaken out - even if it means stepping away for a bit).

15. Make hay while the sun shines.

These conditions don't last forever.

Those who were around in 2017 and 2021 have experienced this first hand.

Take your opportunities. Whether it be airdrops, IDOs, DeFi or trading.

Now is the time to get stuck in the weeds and get involved.

14. Refine your information sources.

Now is the time to organise your Twitter lists/Telegram/Discord/YouTube.

The results you get out are only as good as the information you put in.

13. Leave a moon bag.

It's prudent to take profits after achieving massive gains. But in a bull market, oftentimes the subsequent gains dwarf your actual profits.

Leaving a moon bag (small position) ensures that you retain some exposure in case things truly go parabolic.

12. Don't short.

Fighting the trend is a dangerous game in any trending market.

In crypto, longing offers a better R/R ratio as it has unlimited profit potential with losses limited to the initial investment.

11. Don't rotate.

As tempting as it is, don't get stuck in the loop of rotating profits from one investment to another.

This game of hot potato is all good and well, until you drop it.

It's better to predefine a % of your profits that go into stables vs back into the market.

10. Ladder out.

Making money in a bull market is easy, but keeping it is difficult.

Regularly take profits and siphon them into a separate cold wallet.

I'd rather give up a small % of my potential gains than walk away empty handed.

9. Lower your IQ.

Don't laugh - it works. Evidence? $DOGE, $SHIB, $PEPE etc.

Try not to outsmart yourself.

8. Long the leaders.

Within a narrative, the first mover advantage is substantial.

Often times sticking to the leader of a specific trend is a better R/R play than longing the lower-cap beta plays.

7. Add on dips.

In an uptrend, dips should be treated as a gift.

Focus on accumulating the strong coins that hold up well. These often pump the hardest on the rebound.

6. Zoom out.

People get too caught up on smaller time frames.

This doesn't only apply to buying/selling, but also the time frame in which you evaluate a thesis/idea.

Don't let inconsequential price movements deter you.

5. Don't let corrections shake you out.

During a bull run, the worst thing you can do is get shaken out prematurely.

These dips will psychologically test you, but are completely normal during a bull run.

Minimise leverage on core positions, don't panic, and keep conviction.

4. New coins are gud coins.

The market loves gravitating towards the new, shiny objects.

These will often outperform their older predecessors.

Many of the strongest gainers will be the newly listed tokens, especially those with a low float.

3. When you have a strong thesis, back it with conviction.

Size up when the stars align.

"Play long enough, you never change the stakes, the house takes you. Unless, when that perfect hand comes along, you bet big, and then you take the house." - Oceans 11

2. Accept that hype > fundamentals.

This can a tough pill to swallow.

But in a bull market, hype and speculation are the strongest price drivers.

Focus less on fundamentals and more on understanding market psychology.

1. Keep things simple.

As the market heats up, things can get overwhelming.

More distractions, more opportunities, more noise.

Don't lose focus.

Pick a niche, stay in your lane, find an edge and stick with it.

Accept that you're going to miss opportunities and be ok with it.

Weekly Token + Narrative Watchlist üîé

It has been a crazy start to the week, with meme coin mania taking over. 

Here are the altcoins I'm watching this week.üëá

$WIF + $PEPE: There has been a slew of new meme coin launches on Solana, like $SLERF - with capital rotating from the leaders and into these more speculative trades. However, remember that meme coin rotations happen quickly, and generally end up funnelling back into the leaders.

$SOL: Blasted through its previous ATH in market cap terms, looking for a price ATH next. SOL is essentially the currency of the Solana casino, as SOL is needed to participate in these memecoin presales etc. I'm not a fan of longing into extreme greed, so my attention has shifted to some of the other alt-L1s, although I'm happily riding my SOL position. 

$SUI: Benefits from the recent SOL rally (rising tide lifts all L1 ships). They have a gaming summit on the 20th of March + rumours of some big announcements soon. On my accumulation list.

$APT: People are beginning to coin the term ‚ÄúAptos April‚Äù. Lots of things are seemingly brewing, with top executives teasing big partnerships, and like SUI, it is also part of the L1 trade.

$FTM: Recent price action has been great. Their sonic upgrade is getting closer and closer, but more notably, Andre Cronje is back and pushing it hard. He is tweeting about Sonic, FVM, and more. Fantom is one of those coins that runs hard when momentum is behind it. Still long and looking to add on any major dips.

$BTC: With the interest rate decision on Wednesday, I'm interested to see how Bitcoin reacts to these major macro events, given it's been running in isolation recently. There is no chance of a rate cut, but given how legitimised the space is becoming (with the ETF), I'm curious to see how it affects flows.

$LUNC + $LUNA: Did someone say SOLUNAVAX? Watching for some volatility on these. Do Kwon‚Äôs trial starts in a week, and these tokens tend to be volatile around these events, either driven by updates or news. This is on the watchlist as a potential trade if a decent setup presents. Remember, it's meme season. üòâ

$MASK: Announced upcoming mask staking earlier today. Individual holders may stake their $MASK tokens for the opportunity to receive additional tokens from their core partners and ecosystem projects. Additionally, in Feb they announced a $100m ecosystem fund. Lots of tailwinds.

$AVAX: Continues to perform strongly, and is following the L1 Solana "catch up" trade chart wise (if you compare to SOL). On-chain metrics are improving, and they're pushing hard in the gaming space, recently solidifying a partnership with Maple Universe.

AI TOKENS: We're at an interesting crossroads with AI (shorter term). The last leg up was mostly driven by the NVIDIA AI conference hype, but given that it's starting today, I wonder if it will become a "sell the news" event. If so, any major dips could provide another opportunity to accumulate. Conversely, any major announcements could have a positive effect. Wait and see.

That wraps up the weekly watchlist. Give this post a Like + Retweet if you're enjoying the series! üíô

There has been a paradigm shift to the crypto market dynamics over the past 2 days.

I'll explain how.

There are currently 3 camps of "retail", each with a very different motive/perspective: "The Old Guard", "Fresh", and "Crypto-Native".

1. "The old guard" are logging onto Coinbase/Robinhood for the first time in years, and are seeing their old bags (like $XRP, $ADA, $DOGE etc) up massively. They then tell their friends, who are already familiar with these tokens, so there is less mental friction when it comes to entering a new position/holding these coins.

2. "Fresh" retail are those who weren't around in 2021, and are mostly coming into crypto to jump into the memecoin casino. They see the crazy pumps on TikTok, Reddit, from their friends etc. and are downloading Solana/moonshot wallets to ape on-chain memes (many of which constitute a younger demographic).

3. Then, you have CT ("crypto-native") retail, who are more experienced, have probably outperformed the majority of this year, but are now experiencing the first week of underperforming (likely still making money, but just less than other sectors). Many of which are now feeling like they're "mid-curving".

It's created this very weird simultaneous combination of:

- CT feeling confused/coping because their bags are underperforming whilst "dino coins" are pumping
- "Dino coin" maxis (like $XRP and $ADA) dunking on the former (they've had to watch their coins suffer whilst memes outperform for months - so let's call it letting off some steam)
- On-chain maxis making/losing stupid amounts of money
- People FOMOing into all of the above

It feels like, for the first time in a while, all segments of the market are completely detached.

But I want to make it clear: Whatever camp you're in - this is bullish for the entire space.

More attention = more liquidity, and in a true altcoin season (which this current "meta" could certainly trigger), everything has it's time to shine (as long as it has a strong narrative/community).

So lock in, prepare your bags, be happy for other's success, because we're all going to win together. This may be the beginning of something much bigger.

4. Volume profile

Like the Stoch RSI, this is not a primary price action tool.

3. Stochastic RSI

To take our learning one step further, we can add a Stochastic RSI.

This tool helps you analyse overbought/oversold scenarios.

It's great in conjunction with S/R levels and a momentum indicator

The key to this prompt is asking o3 if the Stoch RSI confirms or denies what we see on the S/R and 200D MA levels (as those are our main price action tools).

The reason why the "cycle top is in/we're late" discussion is so polarising, is because the market falls into 2 camps:

A) Those who have already made a significant amount of money are naturally going to shift into preservation mode (wind down phase)

B) Those who haven't achieved their goals yet and are searching for opportunity (wind up phase)

Both camps are operating on very different time frames, and their thinking is biased towards their objective (to preserve vs create wealth).

So those are the 10 reasons why I believe the crypto market is poised to turn around in Q4.

There may still be shakeouts (the road is always bumpy in crypto), but i do anticipate by mid-next year, things are much higher.

10. FTX is repaying $16B to creditors.

The Mt. Gox/German selling caused massive downside.

But, the FTX repayments are the exact OPPOSITE (cash injection vs cash extraction).

$12b will be paid out in cash, with many users likely to funnel this capital back into the market.

This is a powerful dynamic, as heightened off-side positioning typically leads to more aggressive expansionary phases.

This, in and of itself, is a major reason why I believe the best is still yet to come.

Another interesting data point is the Coinbase App ranking.

Let's now turn our attention to some CRYPTO-SPECIFIC factors which have the potential to impact markets in Q4.

Starting simply with an observation:

8. Global liquidity is on the rise.

Out of EVERY single variable, $BTC is the MOST correlated to global liquidity. More so than equities or gold.

Global Liquidity has already started increasing, and is forecasted to continue rising into 2025.

7. The weakening of the US dollar.

A Federal Reserve rate cut would also lead to the weakening of the Dollar Index, which would act as a boon for risk on assets such as equities and $BTC.

Whilst I've seen the common take that rate cuts are bearish, the data suggests that they are only bearish when they're for recessionary reasons.

In fact, during non-recessionary periods, the first rate cut has been bullish.

6. Inflation is cooling down, and rate cuts are coming.

The recent CPI reading was the lowest since February 2021.

Powell has been vocal about inflation being brought under control, and a FED pivot is potentially only days away.

5. The market may not be (fully) pricing in a Trump presidency.

As it sits (according to Polymarket) the odds are roughly 50/50.

When Trump recently spoke at the BTC 2024 conference, he glowingly endorsed Bitcoin and crypto.

If elected, I think markets respond favourably.

4. The election.

We're less than 2 months away from the US federal election.

I'll be straight: I do believe a Trump presidency is much better for crypto.

However, Kamala winning isn't a death blow imo - it might just limit upside + create regulatory issues down the track.

@crypto_oc1 You can have rough ideas. But these shouldn't be fixed.

Price targets and portfolio targets are stupid. 

Here's why.

The #1 way people rekt themselves last cycle (myself included to some extent), was by holding onto hope of reaching some arbitrary number.

In many cases, this was $100k BTC.

Or, they had a personal portfolio target number in their head (whether it be $100k, $1m etc.) 

Here's the thing: THE WORLD DOESN'T CARE ABOUT YOUR NUMBER.

It's not worth round tripping your entire portfolio, just for the sake of maybe hitting some arbitrary number.

Instead, do 2 things:

1. Remain adaptive: If your goal is a 10x, but the market starts looking toppy (and your portfolio is only at a 4x), with LTF confluence to match your HTF bias, then take profits. It's better to walk away up a 4x vs round tripping entirely.

2. Implement an incremental profit taking system: For each coin you buy, have a plan to shift out set %s at certain multiples (e.g. every time $TAO goes up +50%, I will take 10% of my total stack off the table). 

You can get progressively more aggressive with profit taking as the cycle matures.

What matters most is the ability to judge where we are in the cycle, and position accordingly - as opposed to holding out for some arbitrary target you have set for yourself.

Don't get me wrong - having a goal is a good thing. 

But that goal should be fluid based on the market and its signals.

If not, you're just playing a lottery.

Celebrating my 24th birthday today with some sushi. ü•≥ 

The past year has been undoubtedly the craziest of my life. 

I‚Äôve experienced both the highs (and lows) of newfound wealth, moving to an entirely new continent away from family/friends, mental health, personal growth & more.

I thought I'd take this opportunity to share some of my biggest learnings/observations I've had over this past year. Maybe some of you will find them valuable.

1. Live in the present, not the future or the past. 

I‚Äôve been making a concerted effort to focus on being present, and also looking more objectively at my thoughts and emotions - instead of getting lost in them.

2. Discipline beats intelligence every day of the week, and twice on Sunday. 

I‚Äôve always intrinsically ‚Äúknown‚Äù this, but this is the year where it REALLY set in. Most of my success thus far isn‚Äôt attributed to natural ability, so much as it is my diligence. 

I recognize that my ambition/obsessiveness may be a (somewhat) natural trait, but I‚Äôve really learnt to lean into it to get what I want (gamifying tasks, setting fun goals etc). Eventually discipline compounds and creates remarkable outcomes. 

3. The importance of family/friends. 

This is probably the biggest thing I‚Äôve sacrificed since moving to Dubai. And at times it's been tough.

Firstly, I have newfound appreciation for my parents, and everything they‚Äôve done for me. As I‚Äôve moved away, I‚Äôve had time to reflect on just how pivotal they‚Äôve been in my success. 

As for friends, you really can‚Äôt win at life without them. The world is a pretty lonely place when you have no one to share your success (or downfalls) with. I probably value and recognize real relationships much more than I previously did. 

4. Getting ‚Äúrich‚Äù isn‚Äôt what I thought it would be. 

Don‚Äôt get me wrong, being rich is still 10x better than the alternative. But it won‚Äôt solve all your problems, your loneliness, or your mental health issues. In fact, it probably compounds these issues. Not to mention the paranoia attached to keeping wealth. Half the battle is earning it, but keeping it is just as difficult - and it‚Äôs not something you can ever really be prepared for until you‚Äôre in that position. It‚Äôs a good problem to have, of course, but it‚Äôs still another obstacle to navigate.

5. Health is all we have. 

Money is useless if you‚Äôre sick. I was lucky this year not to run into many complications, but there were short periods where I fell quite ill and it really hit home. Especially now that my job relies on my productivity. It wasn‚Äôt like that at school, or when I had a 9-5, because you were always compensated for being sick. Now, if I‚Äôm sick - I literally lose thousands of dollars per day (in opportunity cost). I prioritize health over everything nowadays (sleep, exercise, diet *just let me eat my sushi, ok?* üòÇ)

6. Balance is important. 

Making money, in and of itself, isn‚Äôt a sustainable source of joy (at least not for 99% of people). You need other things in your life. Hobbies that are genuinely fulfilling. Recently I‚Äôve started connecting with my musical side again (piano and singing). It feels good. Sport is also something I‚Äôm getting back into (padel and tennis mainly). It‚Äôs not only a great way of burning calories, but also fun/social.

Overall, I feel extremely grateful to be in the position I am at my age. Not just financially, but the experiences and opportunity I've been given to grow as a person. I also feel more settled with who I am than I ever have been, but I‚Äôm still aware of my own weaknesses and am eager to improve.

Hopefully 24 can teach me some more valuable lessons and provide another platform to grow.

Thank you all for being on this journey with me. üíô

If I'm investing in a high-conviction altcoin long-term, I like to split my holdings into 2 parts:

1. Long-term bag (I won't trade it, only take profit)
2. Active trading bag (I'll use high-time-frame invalidations/key levels on the chart to enter and exit)

The latter requires more attention, but this way I benefit from the upside of my long-term thesis without full exposure to the downside.

The percentage you assign to each depends on your conviction.

It could be 80/20 for something you're very bullish on.

Or 20/80 for more of a "long-shot" play.

Just ensure you define your exact strategy before making a purchase.

Well, it's not an exact science - but there are some signals we can use to spot a squeeze before it happens.

Let me break them down.

‚Ä¢ Deeply negative funding rates: An excess of shorts in the market sets ideal conditions
‚Ä¢ Sudden spikes in open interest and volume: Signifies traders positioning themselves ahead of the move
‚Ä¢ Low-liquidity altcoins: These are easier to manipulate and more volatile during squeezes

Coins under these parameters can move explosively to the upside at any time, especially in sectors that were heavily beaten down, like memes and AI.

That's why the biggest moves in the last few days have been on coins with CEX perp listings, which have been heavily shorted.

But how can you work out which ones are next?

‚Ä¢ Initial price move forces liquidations
‚Ä¢ Liquidations add buying pressure, pushing prices even higher
‚Ä¢ People speculate on further upside, resulting in increased long interest

Why is this happening?

Many alts have been heavily shorted, as funding rates ticked extremely negative across the market.

However, when prices begin to move higher, as we've been seeing, short sellers are forced to close their positions.

This triggers a wave of liquidations, creating a self-reinforcing price surge.

Since then, we've started to see alts pull some crazy moves.

Short squeeze season is here.

The key to winning in crypto is AWARENESS.

You don't need a complex system.

Just be aware of what's happening and react accordingly.

Keep your long term portfolio simple, especially if you're trading.

Ideally 5-10 coins max.

It will take less time to manage, and free up your mind to take advantage of other trading opportunities.

The best coins to trade short-term, are ironically the coins you hold long-term.

Why?

If you have long-term conviction in a project, chances are you're regularly keeping up to date with fundamental changes + price action.

Pattern recognition in trading is very important.

And this can only be built over time (by witnessing how price responds to certain events).

Many of my best short-term trades are also coins I hold in my long-term spot portfolio.

As cycles progress, so does the intensity of sentiment swings.

Your only job is to cut out the noise and focus. https://t.co/n36uxGBcFd

A common trap crypto investors fall for is focusing too much on the asset class, as opposed to asset selection.

Each coin you buy or hold is its own individual trade.

Focus on getting each individual trade right and executing proper risk management on said trades, as opposed to focusing on the entire market.

It's probably counterintuitive to how most people behave, but it's even more important to adopt this mental framework this cycle due to the amount of attention/liquidity fragmentation.
